BOOK.CONTENTTEXT1: The more abstract contents of theoretical computer science are motivated by practical examples out clearly taught and consolidated in exercises. The whole text of the book runs through the project to develop a compiler for a language for graphical effects. The necessary contributions are progressively created and aspects of automated compiler generation are discussed.
BOOK.TITLE: Formal languages, abstract automata and compilers
BOOK.SUBTITLE: Textbook for undergraduate studies
BOOK.CONTENTTEXT2: For modeling of formal languages, regular expressions, abstract automata and for automated compiler generation from a graphic-visual description AtoCC provides mutual interconnected components. The learning and working environment AtoCC was developed specifically for the study of theoretical computer science and already successfully used at several universities and schools. AtoCC deepened theoretical knowledge through practical exercises and attractive application projects from the graphics and audio. Translation and processing more or less complicated languages, we now find, for example, also in modern web applications.
BOOK.TOPICSTEXT: Structure of programs - Fundamental terms - Definitions of infinite sets - Compilers - Finite automata - Regular languages and regular expressions - Pushdown automata and context-free languages - LL(k) langauges - LR(K) languages - Parser and parser generators - Project on language translation - Mealy- and Moore machines - Turing machine and Chomsky-type-0/1 languages
BOOK.TARGETTEXT: Computer science students at universities of applied science, mainly research oriented universities, and universities of cooperative education as well as teachers at extended secondary schools (gymnasia).

LANGUAGES.DEFALPHABET: An alphabet is any finite and non empty set of symbols.
LANGUAGES.DEFWORD: A word w over an alphabet A is a finite sequence, or string, of zero or more symbols taken from A. ε simply stands for the empty word "".
LANGUAGES.BUILDWORDHINT: Repeatedly left-click a symbol to gradually construct a particular word.
LANGUAGES.DEFLANGUAGE: A language L⊆A* is a set of words over A. It is either a finite or a countable infinite set.
LANGUAGES.DEFWORDSET: The set of words A* is the set of all words over an alphabet A, including the empty word ε.
LANGUAGES.SELECTALPHABET: Choose one of the alphabets as follows to experiment with.
LANGUAGES.DELETECHARSHINT: Left-click a symbol to remove it.
LANGUAGES.DEFWORDLENGTH: The length of a word w, |w| for short, is the number of symbols in it.
LANGUAGES.BUILDLANGUAGEHINT: Form a language L by left-clicking of some particular words of A*.
LANGUAGES.DEFLANGUAGELIMITS: Formal languages which are provided for practical applications are usually countable infinite. How can they be definined?
LANGUAGES.ALTERNATIVEHINT: Some countable infinite languages can be definied for example as follows
LANGUAGES.ALLWORDSSTARTINGWITH: L1 = all words of A* that start with the symbol
LANGUAGES.ALLWORDSSHORTERTHEN: L2 = all words of A* whose lengths are less than or equal
LANGUAGES.ALLWORDSSAMEAMOUNT: L4 = all words of A* that contain the same number of

REFERENCE.R2: Matches the sequenz of the characters a b and c in this order
REFERENCE.R3: Matches any of the alternatives specified
REFERENCE.R4: Matches any character between the brackets
REFERENCE.R5: Matches any character NOT between the brackets
REFERENCE.R7: Matches any character not a digit
REFERENCE.R8: Matches at least one n or more occurrences of n
REFERENCE.R9: Matches zero or more occurrences of n
REFERENCE.R10: Matches zero or one occurrences of n
REFERENCE.R11: Matches a single character, except newline or line terminator
REFERENCE.R12: Matches the character [. Always escape special characters!

KFGEDIT.CANNOTTRANSORMWITHOUTREGULAR: The grammar is not regular. Therefore, it can not be transformed into a NFA.
KFGEDIT.TOOMANYTREES: There are more than one, possibly infinitely many parse trees for the word {{INPUT}}.
KFGEDIT.DERIVEERROR: The word {{INPUT}} could not be derived.
KFGEDIT.DELETEGRAMMARASK: Do you really want to delete the grammar {{NAME}}?
KFGEDIT.HOWTO:
Here is how a grammar has to be defined in FLACI:
  • Note the production rules.
  • Terminal symbols may be included with ' (like 'pi'). Wheras the terminal symbols are colored in blue the nonterminals are in red.
  • By convention, the left-sided nonterminal of the first rule is the start symbol of the grammar.
  • Consider for example a grammar of palindromes over {a,b}*:
    S -> a | b | EPSILON | a S a | b S b
  • Write EPSILON for ε:
    S -> EPSILON | a
  • The dot notation (ellipsis) reduces the effort for writing of all rules.:
    a ... z | 0 ... 9.
KFGEDIT.RANDOMWORD: Generate a random word of L(G) to parse

CONVERT.TONEAHINT: Transforms a regular gammar into an equivalent nondeterministic finite automaton.
CONVERT.TONKAHINT: Transforms a context-free grammar into an equivalent nondeterministic pushdown automaton.

TRANSFORM.CHECKLL1HINT:
• Requirement 1: The FIRST sets of all sentential forms representing the right hand side of the rules for a selected nonterminal have to be pairwise disjoint.
  • Requirement 2: For each nonterminal that can be derived to ɛ whose FIRST set and FOLLOW set have to be disjoint.
TRANSFORM.ISREGULARHINT: It checks if all production rules of the grammar are either in the form X → aY (right-linear) or on X → Ya (left-linear). In addition, terminal-generating rules are permitted.
TRANSFORM.TOCNFHINT:
• A context-free grammar G is said to be in Chomsky normal form (CNF) if all productions are in one of two simple forms, either:
    1. A → a, where A is nonterminal and 'a' is a terminal and A, or
    2. A → BC, where A, B, and C are each nonterminals.
  • To put a CFG in CNF start with a grammar that has no ɛ-rules, unit productions, or useless symbols.
  • Arrange that all sentential forms of length 2 or more on the right hand sides of all rules consist only of nonterminals.
  • For rules with a right hand sides length of 3 or more substitute a cascade of productions with exactly two nonterminals one their right hand.
TRANSFORM.INSERTEPSILONHINT:
To add ε to the CFL L(G) you have
  • to introduce a new nonterminal s' to be the new start symbol of G and
  • to add two new rules for s', namely s' → s | ε, where s is the previous start symbol of G.
TRANSFORM.REMOVEEPSILONHINT:
• Find all m nonterminals A which are nullable, i.e., A *⇒ ɛ.
  • For all rules that contain one ore more nullable symbols on their right-hand side substitute the productions with all 2m possible combinations of the given sentential form where nullable symbols are present or absent.
TRANSFORM.SIMPLIFYHINT:
• Nonterminals that are not reachable from the start symbol of the grammar will be removed.
  • ...
TRANSFORM.REMOVELOOPSHINT:
• Prepare all pairs of nonterminals (A,B), where A*&rBrr; B.
  • All productions for B are assigned to A, except for rules B → X, where X is a single nonterminal on the right.
TRANSFORM.REMOVELEFTRECHINT: • Apply the Paull's algorithm to a CFG without both ɛ-rules and unit productions.
TRANSFORM.LEFTFACTORHINT: The longest common prefix α of all sentential forms for a certain nonterminal X will be excluded, like this: X →	α X', where X' defines the respective rest of the sentential form behind α.

LL1.TITLE: Check of the LL(1) requirements
LL1.NOEPSILON: Because ɛ is not an item of the FIRST-set, the requirement 2 is fulfilled automatically.

ABOUT.FLACITEXT: FLACI (short hand for formal languages, automata, compilers, and interpeters) is a learning environment for teaching selected theoretical aspects of computer science in particular the theory of formal languages, theory of automata, and applications in the field of compiler construction. FLACI supports activities to acquire techniques of abstraction as they are increasingly used in both professional software development and high level programming concepts.
ABOUT.FLACIREF: FLACI is a joint research project of the Hochschule Zittau/Görlitz and the Pädagogische Hochschule Schwyz.
ABOUT.FLACIBASE: FLACI is based on experiences gained from the previous tool AtoCC from the year 2012 and running on the desktop.
ABOUT.FLACIAUTHORS: Project management: Dr. Michael Hielscher and Prof. Dr. Christian Wagenknecht
ABOUT.FLACISTUDENTS: Students who contributed to the project (names are listed in alphabetical order)
ABOUT.FLACISTUDENTLIST: Stefan Bradl, Ronald Krause, Dana Müller, Alexander Preuß, Robert Rosenberger, Tobias Salzmann, Robert Stricker, Ralf Zücker
